) The Reporting Compliance Case Management System (RCCMS) is used to create and control examination cases. (
) Cases in RCCMS have an electronic copy of the return and / or related research material regarding the case. (

) Examiners working cases may prepare, develop and store workpapers within the RCCMS system. Users may also use Microsoft Office software and Adobe pdf ﬁles, along with forms, letters, and templates in the RCCMS repository. (
) Examiners may use Leadsheets, in RCCMS, which correspond to each of Form
, EO Workpaper Summary (EO cases) or Form
, Examina- tion Workpapers (FSL/ET cases). (

) Examiners may maintain in-process and completed workpapers in RCCMS synchronize with the central database. The synchronization works as an automatic backup of stored data ﬁles in the central database server. (

) A RCCMS electronic case ﬁle should closely resemble a paper case ﬁle’s content. This includes all workpapers and pertinent source documents you to determine whether there are any issues or changes that you’ll discuss or resolve before you close the case.

) Compliance, Planning and Classiﬁcation (CP&C) inputs tracking codes on all examination cases before they send them to the ﬁeld. (
) The tracking codes identify an issue-category for risk-based compliance strate- gies approach to prioritizing EO examinations. (
) CP&C also puts the tracking codes on the cover sheet in the examination ﬁle.
Note: When you pick up and establish additional returns, use the tracking code of the previously established return that generated the pick-up. Don’t change an assigned tracking code.
Case is deﬁned as the primary return (or other selected return) open for ex

amination for one year (or tax period) plus other returns, if any, involving interrelated interests and/or transactions that require concurrent examinations. Other returns include the taxpayer’s returns subsequent and/or prior to the primary return (or other selected return) and returns for related taxpayers for the primary year and subsequent and/or prior years.

Primary Return is the annual EO information return under EO jurisdiction and the tax returns under the jurisdiction of FSL/ET around which other returns revolve. Primary returns report all aspects of an organization’s ﬁnancial and/or operational activities. The primary return also serves as the return-of-record for statute purposes. ) IDRS is the Integrated Data Retrieval System, a major application of databases and operating programs that support IRS employees working tax cases. This system allows IRS employees to take speciﬁc actions on taxpayer account issues, track status and post transaction updates to the Master Files (MF). IDRS updates are done in both a batch process and through online interactive real-time programs Command Codes. Employees take actions via IDRS for: • Notice issuance. • Installment agreement processing. • Offers in compromise. • Adjustment processing. • Penalty and interest computations and explanations. • Credit and debit transfers within an account. • Other related accounts and research of taxpayer accounts to resolve taxpayer inquiries and problems. (

) Command codes (CC) are used to access taxpayer account information through IDRS. The codes consist of ﬁve alpha characters in a speciﬁc format. Speciﬁc information can be obtained through an additional called a deﬁner code. (
) Deﬁner codes are typically alpha characters placed at the end of a code to obtain more speciﬁc information. (
) MFT is short for Master File Tax, a speciﬁc type of account code required each transaction to identify the speciﬁc type of return module to which a action is being posted. For example, Form
returns have an MFT of
Form
-T returns have an MFT of
) Tax module is the part of a taxpayer’s account which reﬂects tax data for tax class (MFT) and one tax period. For example, a taxpayer has ﬁled Forms
The taxpayer has only one account, but three tax modules. (
) Transaction Codes (TC) are three-digit codes used to identify actions on a taxpayer’s account. Transaction codes are most commonly posted to speciﬁc tax modules. (

) Document Locator Number (DLN) is a controlled number assigned to return or document input through the Account Data Processing system. fourteenth (last) digit is the year of processing and is assigned by the computer at the time of the original input. (
) The ﬁrst ﬁve letters constitute the command code, and the sixth character deﬁner code. Codes (

) BMFOLO provides information on an exempt organization. (
) BMFOLR is the return information screen, containing a brief summary of entries from the return. (
) BMFOLT provides a transcript of transactions on a tax module. (
) BMFOLU is used to view Combined Annual Wage Reporting (CAWR) tion. (
) BMFOLZ is the examination history screen, displaying the closing codes assessment amounts of prior examinations. (
) BRTVU (Business Return Transaction View) provides an in-depth display business return information. It is only available for the three most recent years.

Under the case law, the following factors must exist for the return to be valid.: a. There must be sufficient data to calculate the tax liability. b. The document must purport to be a return. c. There must be an honest and reasonable attempt to satisfy the require- ments of the tax law. d. The taxpayer must execute the return under penalties of perjury. Caution: These factors don’t take into account the processing concerns that an incomplete return presents for the Service. Therefore, approach any question concerning the validity of a return missing a form or schedule with the presumption that there’s sufficient data to calculate the tax liability. ) Both the examiner and the manager are responsible to do a risk analysis on every examination case. The level of the sophistication of risk analysis depends on the case’s size and complexity and resources being considered the examination. Depending upon the circumstances, this may range from notations in the CCR or workpapers to a formal risk analysis document. (

) Materiality is used in risk analysis to prioritize the issues and LUQ items considered, and to focus on the items of greatest compliance concern. ality is both a qualitative and quantitative assessment we use to identify which are most relevant and consequential in determining:
Continued tax exempt status.
Overall accuracy and completeness of the primary EO information (Form
-PF, etc.).
Correct tax liability (income, employment, excise). (

) The process of evaluating materiality should be consistently applied, but the result is different for each case. Absolute parameters can’t be established or used for every case because of the differences in size, complexity, and status of the organization’s returns being examined, as well as the in the experience and professional judgment of the examiners and managers. (

) In assessing an issue or LUQ’s materiality, consider the factors listed below. This isn’t an exhaustive list and there may be other relevant materiality that you should consider. Exempt Organizations Examination Procedures
The following examples illustrate potential examination situations when you should secure a POA or TIA form: Example

: The president of the organization advises that Mr. Monroe, the accountant who prepared the organization’s returns, will be the contact point for receiving information and correspondence relating to the examination and providing information to and discuss- ing issues. Mr. Monroe is an unenrolled return preparer. Secure a POA form for Mr. Monroe.

Example 2: The president of the organization advises that Mr. the bookkeeper, will be the contact point for receiving tax information and correspondence relating to the examination and providing infor- mation. The organization doesn’t wish to authorize Mr. Carroll to sign agreements, consents, or represent the organization as a POA. Secure a written or verbal TIA for Mr. Carroll.

Example 4: The organization’s attorney has a valid POA form to represent the organization. He has his secretary call to determine the status of the examination. The secretary doesn’t have the right to receive conﬁdential tax information concerning the organization. Don’t discuss the status of the examination with the secretary unless you secure a verbal or written TIA.

) The following sections describe scenarios that can impair the examiner’s ability to conduct the examination. Scenario #

: What to do when you can’t ﬁnd an organization, or the initial letter is returned undeliverable. This scenario can occur for several reasons: a. The organization may recently have gone out of business, and hasn’t formally dissolved. b. The organization has no permanent physical address, with the address shifting to the address of a newly elected officer each year. c. The organization may have merged with another exempt organi- zation, such as the forced mergers of lodges or posts, directed to do so by parent organizations. d. The address of an organization is intentionally misleading, refer- encing a mailbox as a suite. e. The officers of the organization are involved in tax avoidance transactions and are attempting to make locating the organiza- tion difficult. Note: Examples d. and e. are indicators of organizations that may not be operated for the exempt purposes outlined in the deter- mination application. When you encounter these cases, ask the Forensic Investigations Unit (FIU) for suggestions. Scenario #

: When the organization requests the case be transferred to either another examiner, to another office in the area or to another area altogether. Some of these requests for transfers may be valid if the records are physically located other than where they are listed on the Form
or if a related examination is already being done by

Scenario #2: When the organization requests the case be transferred to either another examiner, to another office in the area or to another area altogether. Some of these requests for transfers may be valid if the records are physically located other than where they are listed on the Form 990 or if a related examination is already being done by another examiner in another office. Others of these requests may constitute attempts by the officers, trustees, employees, or represen- tatives of the organization to delay, hinder, or derail the examination. In all transfer situations, discuss with your manager. See IRM 4.75.10.12.2, Request for Transfer.

Some of the most commonly used forms to request research from IRS’ internal sources are listed below:
IDRS is the Service’s system that enables employees to have access to taxpayer accounts and infor- mation. Some of its capabilities are:
Different ﬁles comprise the IDRS database. Two of the most familiar ﬁles used by all IRS operating divisions are:

a. AIMS - This ﬁle manages IRS’ inventory of open returns (and closed returns for a limited time). For example, the examiner can check the status of a return on AIMS by requesting command code AMDISA. b. CFOL - This ﬁle provides MF information on line immediately and is used for research only. No data can be entered on the account. For example, the examiner can request account and return information through command codes BMFOLT and BRTVU.

The examiner must use the forms listed above to access information for various pre-contact purposes, such as veriﬁcation of establishment on AIMS, SOL date, penalties assessed (or not), on ﬁle, amount of tax paid, ﬁling status and statute dates of related returns, exempt status of an nization and more.
Command codes and their descriptions are listed in Document
(ADP and IDRS Information). This book also contains exhibits and keys to the information displayed from research results, which helps the examiner interpret the data obtained.

Although IRS examiners have a wide variety of information available to them and should use it needed, the conﬁdentiality of tax return information and the taxpayer’s privacy are of utmost impor- tance. Unauthorized access to taxpayer account information, browsing, is illegal, and offenders are prosecuted under the provisions of RRA
